message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the Earth's rotation and the celestial bodies that affect day and night. The closest yellow dwarf star to Earth is the Sun, which rises in the east and sets in the west, causing the cycles of day and night. Option (A) is incorrect because gas giant planets do not rise and set like stars do. Option (B) is incorrect because galaxies are much larger structures and do not rise or set. This question requires basic knowledge about the movement of celestial bodies and the Earth's rotation. The closest yellow dwarf star to Earth is the sun, and it is responsible for the cycles of day and night. During the day, the sun rises in the east, reaches its highest point in the sky at noon, and sets in the west, causing daytime. At night, when the sun is not visible, it creates the darkness that is associated with night time. Option (A) is incorrect because gas giant planets do not rise and set in the same way as stars. Option (B) is incorrect because another galaxy near ours would not affect the cycles of day and night on Earth. Option (C) is incorrect because the closest planet to Earth is Venus, and it does not cause the cycles of day and night.
